title: EAST LONDON BANGLADESHIS AND MENTAL HEALTH: RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN RELIGIOUS AND PROFESSIONAL HEALTH SECTORS
abstractText:
This project aims to examine the experiences of thirty members of the East London Bangladeshi community who suffer with mental illness, and also the experiences of their carers.  It explores conceptualisations of, and attitudes towards, mental illness among Bangladeshis in Tower Hamlets and their health seeking behaviour in relation to their illness, and  the relationships between the religious sectors and mainstream psychiatric services.  It uses a community participation approach in which members of the community will be actively involved in developing and monitoring the research project and reviewing its outcomes in terms of proposals for future service development. 

The study will consist of three components:

  • a pre-study cultural appropriateness focus group,
  • an ethnographic study of patients attending a day centre and their families in Tower Hamlets,
  • a post study focus group to discuss dissemination of findings.

It will provide data concerning problems which members of this community encounter while attending mainstream psychiatric services including issues of racism, gender inequality, stigma, and lack of cultural sensitivity.  Additionally it will provide information about how religious frameworks inform knowledge of mental illness and how these frameworks are useful in treatment.
